questions.text: A 23-year-old man traveling on vacation in the Maldives noted some mild abdominal cramps and three or four unformed stools over the past 24 hours. No blood was seen in the stool. Which of the following drugs would be appropriate to treat the patient's diarrhea?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bismuth subsalicylate Reason-B The patient is most likely affected by travelers’ diarrhea, which typically begins within 24 to 48 hours after eating focally contaminated food. Several Enterobacteriaceae can cause travelers’ diarrhea, varying according to the area of travel. Bismuth subsalicylate is effective in patients with diarrhea caused by E. coli, Helicobacter pylori, Campylobacter jejune, and Salmonella species and also inhibits enteric secretions.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man was admitted to the hospital because of prolonged, massive watery diarrhea for the past 2 days. Physical and lab exams indicated a pancreatic tumor, and radioimmunoassay confirmed the diagnosis of VIPoma. The patient was given intravenous fluids for hydration and was scheduled for surgery. Which of the following drugs would be appropriate to control the patient's diarrhea?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Octreotide Reason-Octreotide is a somatostatin analog. When given in pharmacological amounts, somatostatin inhibits virtually all exocrine and endocrine secretions of the pancreas (insulin, glucagon, and pancreatic enzymes), stomach (gastrin), and intestine (secretin, motilin, vasoactive intestinal polypeptide [VIP], gastric inhibitory polypeptide [GIP], and serotonin), as well as secretion of growth hormone, thyroid-stimulating hormone, parathyroid hormone, calcitonin, and adrenocorticotropic hormone. Because of this, octreotide is used to reduce symptoms caused by a variety of hormone-secreting tumors.
